blog.name: jonandtormundendgame
blog.title: My Jonmund Posts Wouldnt Show Up In The Tag

summary:
Jon: What, are you saying me and Arya don’t fit in?
Sansa: Of course not, you’re our siblings and we love you. 
Bran: I used to...
body:
Jon: What, are you saying me and Arya don’t fit in?

Sansa: Of course not, you’re our siblings and we love you.

Bran: I used to dream about you two being kidnapped and it was very peaceful. Those days were easier.

Arya: Honestly? That’s fair.

blog.name: syfygirl1998
blog.title: Running With Wolves
blog.description: 19, bi, would kill for Gendry Baratheon marauders_instrument on Instagram

summary: Arya Stark did not deserve to end up alone.
body:
I’m getting annoyed with people who are trying to defend the terrible writing decision to have Arya sail away from her entire family- Jon, Sansa, kind-of Bran, Gendry. Not only is it a betrayal to her entire character and purpose but to book-Arya as well.

What’s really disappointing is that if the situation was reverse everyone (especially the people trying to defend Arya sailing into almost certain doom for no reason) would react differently to it. For example, if Gendry decided to sail away, without a goodbye to anyone and leaves Arya and Davos, everyone would be calling him an arse for shagging her and then leaving. They wouldn’t be trying to excuse it by saying ‘oh he’s been alone for so long, he doesn’t know how to show his love for people’.


It’s bullshit writing and you all know it.

Arya’s ending should have been her staying in Winterfell, in the home she’s been trying to reach the whole show with her sister. Or she should have gone Beyond the Wall with Jon, a place she could be as free and wild as she wanted with her favourite brother. Or she should have stayed on Bran’s Kingsguard, where she could be a warrior and protect her family. Or she should have gone to Storm’s End with Gendry, something that would have shown that Arya can be a strong, badass, warrior queen and still have a family.

Arya Stark did not deserve to end up alone.

tags: I've gone to the dark place
summary: You know that feeling when you’re in the throes of a hyperfixation and all you want to do is write a modern day tale of Arya...
body: You know that feeling when you’re in the throes of a hyperfixation and all you want to do is write a modern day tale of Arya Stark, former president’s daughter who was kidnapped when the president was murdered, who is now a retired assassin and just wants to live in peace and quiet and help her sister Sansa campaign for president but the person who taught her everything she knew, the Hound, wants to have one last murderous road trip together? I hate when that happens.

reblog.comment: You know that feeling when you’re in the throes of a hyperfixation and all you want to do is write a modern day tale of Arya Stark, former president’s daughter who was kidnapped when the president was murdered, who is now a retired assassin and just wants to live in peace and quiet and help her sister Sansa campaign for president but the person who taught her everything she knew, the Hound, wants to have one last murderous road trip together? I hate when that happens.

I hate when that happens.

summary: Jaqen has white and red hair, the colours of weirwood. There's a godswood in Harrenhal Arya gets access to after Weese dies....
question: Jaqen has white and red hair, the colours of weirwood. There's a godswood in Harrenhal Arya gets access to after Weese dies. Arya prays to a weirwood silently, then begins scolding the old gods, and Jaqen tells her not to mock gods. Jaqen then touches the mouth of the red face on white tree. Later, Jaqen cleans his bloody swood on Arya's shift, red on white. After Jaqen leaves, Arya hears what sounds like her father telling her she's Arya of Winterfell. It's like he unmuted the gods or the tree.
answer:
What a great catch, dear anon! I believe Jaqen and Arya were destined to meet. It simply cannot be a coincidence that one of the most important moments in their relationship, if not the most important, happens under the weirwood tree. You are right, it’s like the gods have been guiding Arya since she met Jaqen. There is so much to unravel here. I wish George Martin were more open about the Faceless Men and Arya’s future. He always gives the most cryptic answers when asked about them. Hopefully, he is saving the best for last. Thank you for your insight!

xoxo

tags: a post of ice and fire
summary: If you “can’t relate” to Daenerys Targaryen and Arya Stark because the first is the mother of dragons and the second is a...
body:
If you “can’t relate” to Daenerys Targaryen and Arya Stark because the first is the mother of dragons and the second is a powerful warg/can play the game of faces and that’s something not most girls go through, you better not to claim to relate with any asoiaf/got character. Because all of them live in a pseudo-medieval world while you like in the 21st century and therefore all of them go through things you don’t.

In case you do find another asoiaf/got character relatable but can’t understand why others relate to Dany/Arya, you are just a hypocrite who wants to find excuses to hate on asoiaf/got best girls.

blog.name: mladyandthebastard
blog.title: M'Lady And The Bastard
blog.description:
This blog is dedicated to Arya Stark and Gendry (Waters) from the HBO show Game of Thrones and the book series A Song of Ice and Fire. 
Old blog: Miladyandthebastard

summary: Do you know meaning of this sentence  "You won't be stealing no kisses from a princess" from book? Is it refered to gendry and...
question: Do you know meaning of this sentence  "You won't be stealing no kisses from a princess" from book? Is it refered to gendry and arya? I don't understand. Sorry for my english.
answer:
Hey, Don’t apologise. Yes its from A Storm of Swords - Chapter 39 (Arya’s POV). 

In this chapter Gendry pledges to the brotherhood without banners and is knighted. I couldn’t find the whole chapter but i found a small section. 

“A smith can find a welcome most anywhere. A skilled armorer even more so. Why would you choose to stay with us?“

Arya watched Gendry screw up his stupid face, thinking. “At the hollow hill, what you said about being King Robert’s men, and brothers, I liked that. I liked that you gave the Hound a trial. Lord Bolton just hanged folk or took off their heads, and Lord Tywin and Ser Amory were the same. I’d sooner smith for you.”

“We got plenty of mail needs mending, m'lord,” Jack reminded Lord Beric. “Most we took off the dead, and there’s holes where the death came through.”

“You must be a lackwit, boy,” said Lem. “We’re outlaws. Lowborn scum, most of us, excepting his lordship. Don’t think it’ll be like Tom’s fool songs neither. You won’t be stealing no kisses from a princess, nor riding in no tourneys in stolen armor. You join us, you’ll end with your neck in a noose, or your head mounted up above some castle gate.”

“It’s no more than they’d do for you,” said Gendry.

“Aye, that’s so,” said Jack-Be-Lucky cheerfully. “The crows await us all. M'lord, the boy seems brave enough, and we do have need of what he brings us. Take him, says Jack.”

“And quick,” suggested Harwin, chuckling, “before the fever passes and he comes to his senses.” A wan smile crossed Lord Beric’s lips. “Thoros, my sword.”

This time the lightning lord did not set the blade afire, but merely laid it light on Gendry’s shoulder. “Gendry, do you swear before the eyes of gods and men to defend those who cannot defend themselves, to protect all women and children, to obey your captains, your liege lord, and your king, to fight bravely when needed and do such other tasks as are laid upon you, however hard or humble or dangerous they may be?”

“I do, m'lord.”

The marcher lord moved the sword from the right shoulder to the left, and said, “Arise Ser Gendry, knight of the hollow hill, and be welcome to our brotherhood.”

Lemoncloak is basically saying that living as a outlaw (criminal) isn’t like all the fairy tales, its going to be hard and you’ll most likely end up dead. Alot of old songs/stories about outlaws (For example Robin Hood), mention falling in love with a princess or a lady. Which in those times for a “lowborn” would be next to impossible, almost taboo. As far as it relating to Arya’s and Gendry’s Relationship there’s an argument for both sides.

You could say Lem is just warning him about the risks of living as a outlaw and trying to make sure this is something he really wants. He’s just simply saying its not all its made out to be, and not referring to Arya.

However in Chapter 22 of A Storm of Swords after the Acorn Hall scene, Arya and Gendry return to the main hall, everyone notices the state of Arya’s dress and this happens

Harwin took one look at them and burst out laughing, and Anguy smiled one of his stupid freckly smiles and said, “Are we certain this one is a highborn lady?” But Lem gave Gendry a clout alongside the head. “You want to fight, fight with me! She’s a girl, and half your age! You keep your hands off o’ her, you hear me?”

“I started it ” said Arya. “Gendry was just talking.”

“Leave the boy, Lem,” said Harwin. “Arya did start it, I have no doubt. She was much the same at Winterfell.”

In this scene Lem is clearly reminding Gendry that wrestling with Arya Stark is inappropriate, she’s a girl and half his age. He doesn’t mention Arya’s social status but i have the feeling like its implied. By saying this i feel like Lem is suggesting that the play fight has some sort of sexual/flirting undertones behind it. 

Now if you go back to Chapter 39 you could argue he’s hinting to Gendry that joining the brotherhood won’t improve his social class, he won’t be able to kiss princesses or competing in competitions. He’ll still be lowborn and nothing will change. 

Gendry is well aware of Arya’s status and the divide that this makes, this is made clear in the books. 

In this scene (Chapter 34) Arya meets a young lord and they share a pleasant conversation, Gendry is clearly irritated by this.

Poor Ned seemed to grow more miserable with every mile. “When I wear my helm, the rain beats against the steel and gives me headaches,” he complained. “But when I take it off, my hair gets soaked and sticks to my face and in my mouth.”

“You have a knife,” Gendry suggested. “If your hair annoys you so much, shave your bloody head.”

He doesn’t like Ned. The squire seemed nice enough to Arya; maybe a little shy, but good- natured…

“You have a House?” That was stupid; he was a squire, of course he had a House. “Who are you?”

“My lady?” Ned looked embarrassed. “I’m Edric Dayne, the… the Lord of Starfall.”

Behind them, Gendry groaned. “Lords and ladies,” he proclaimed in a disgusted tone. Arya plucked a withered crabapple off a passing branch and whipped it at him, bouncing it off his thick bull head. “Ow,” he said. “That hurt.” He felt the skin above his eye. “What kind of lady throws crabapples at people?”

“The bad kind,” said Arya, suddenly contrite. She turned back to Ned. “I’m sorry I didn’t know who you were. My lord” …

“That’s not so. He loved my lady mother.”“I’m sure he did, my lady, but -”“She was the only one he loved.”“He must have found that bastard under a cabbage leaf, then,” Gendry said behind them.Arya wished she had another crabapple to bounce off his face. “My father had honor,” she said angrily. “And we weren’t talking to you anyway.

Also in the peach scene(Chapter 29). They are in a brothel and they both get a little jealous.

An old man sat down beside her. “Well, aren’t you a pretty little peach?” His breath smelled near as foul as the dead men in the cages, and his little pig eyes were crawling up and down her. “Does my sweet peach have a name?”

For half a heartbeat she forgot who she was supposed to be. She wasn’t any peach, but she couldn’t be Arya Stark either, not here with some smelly drunk she did not know. “I’m…”

“She’s my sister.” Gendry put a heavy hand on the old man’s shoulder, and squeezed. “Leave her be.”

The man turned, spoiling for a quarrel, but when he saw Gendry’s size he thought better of it. “Your sister, is she? What kind of brother are you? I’d never bring no sister of mine to the Peach, that I wouldn’t.” He got up from the bench and moved off muttering, in search of a new friend.

“Why did you say that?” Arya hopped to her feet. “You’re not my brother.”“That’s right,” he said angrily. “I’m too bloody lowborn to be kin to m’lady high.”Arya was taken aback by the fury in his voice. “That’s not the way I meant it.”“Yes it is.” He sat down on the bench, cradling a cup of wine between his hands. “Go away. I want to drink this wine in peace. Then maybe I’ll go find that black-haired girl and ring her bell for her.”

“But…”“I said, go away. M’lady.”Arya whirled and left him there. A stupid bullheaded bastard boy, that’s all he is. He could ring all the bells he wanted, it was nothing to her.

So maybe Gendry did try to change his social status to get closer to Arya by joining the brotherhood without banners, when he noticed the divide between them, and Lem was reminding him being a lowborn knight wouldn’t change anything. Sadly there is no Gendry POV so we can’t tell. 

So does Lem’s quote refer to Arya and Gendry’s relationship? Yes. Am i grasping at straws? A little. However GRRM has an interesting way of writing and alot of the time he will leave breadcrumbs for us to follow, little hints that lead/hint to the bigger picture. I honestly do think it was a wink towards their relationship and some of Gendry’s intentions behind joining.

Hope you enjoyed my TED Talk

Alot of old songs/stories about outlaws (For example Robin Hood), mention falling in love with a princess or a lady. Which in those times for a “lowborn” would be next to impossible, almost taboo. As far as it relating to Arya’s and Gendry’s Relationship there’s an argument for both sides.

You could say Lem is just warning him about the risks of living as a outlaw and trying to make sure this is something he really wants. He’s just simply saying its not all its made out to be, and not referring to Arya.

However in Chapter 22 of A Storm of Swords after the Acorn Hall scene, Arya and Gendry return to the main hall, everyone notices the state of Arya’s dress and this happens

Harwin took one look at them and burst out laughing, and Anguy smiled one of his stupid freckly smiles and said, “Are we certain this one is a highborn lady?” But Lem gave Gendry a clout alongside the head. “You want to fight, fight with me! She’s a girl, and half your age! You keep your hands off o’ her, you hear me?”

“I started it ” said Arya. “Gendry was just talking.”

“Leave the boy, Lem,” said Harwin. “Arya did start it, I have no doubt. She was much the same at Winterfell.”

In this scene Lem is clearly reminding Gendry that wrestling with Arya Stark is inappropriate, she’s a girl and half his age. He doesn’t mention Arya’s social status but i have the feeling like its implied. By saying this i feel like Lem is suggesting that the play fight has some sort of sexual/flirting undertones behind it. 

Now if you go back to Chapter 39 you could argue he’s hinting to Gendry that joining the brotherhood won’t improve his social class, he won’t be able to kiss princesses or competing in competitions. He’ll still be lowborn and nothing will change. 

Gendry is well aware of Arya’s status and the divide that this makes, this is made clear in the books. 

In this scene (Chapter 34) Arya meets a young lord and they share a pleasant conversation, Gendry is clearly irritated by this.

Poor Ned seemed to grow more miserable with every mile. “When I wear my helm, the rain beats against the steel and gives me headaches,” he complained. “But when I take it off, my hair gets soaked and sticks to my face and in my mouth.”

“You have a knife,” Gendry suggested. “If your hair annoys you so much, shave your bloody head.”

He doesn’t like Ned. The squire seemed nice enough to Arya; maybe a little shy, but good- natured…

“You have a House?” That was stupid; he was a squire, of course he had a House. “Who are you?”

“My lady?” Ned looked embarrassed. “I’m Edric Dayne, the… the Lord of Starfall.”

Behind them, Gendry groaned. “Lords and ladies,” he proclaimed in a disgusted tone. Arya plucked a withered crabapple off a passing branch and whipped it at him, bouncing it off his thick bull head. “Ow,” he said. “That hurt.” He felt the skin above his eye. “What kind of lady throws crabapples at people?”

“The bad kind,” said Arya, suddenly contrite. She turned back to Ned. “I’m sorry I didn’t know who you were. My lord” …

“That’s not so. He loved my lady mother.”“I’m sure he did, my lady, but -”“She was the only one he loved.”“He must have found that bastard under a cabbage leaf, then,” Gendry said behind them.Arya wished she had another crabapple to bounce off his face. “My father had honor,” she said angrily. “And we weren’t talking to you anyway.

Also in the peach scene(Chapter 29). They are in a brothel and they both get a little jealous.

An old man sat down beside her. “Well, aren’t you a pretty little peach?” His breath smelled near as foul as the dead men in the cages, and his little pig eyes were crawling up and down her. “Does my sweet peach have a name?”

For half a heartbeat she forgot who she was supposed to be. She wasn’t any peach, but she couldn’t be Arya Stark either, not here with some smelly drunk she did not know. “I’m…”

“She’s my sister.” Gendry put a heavy hand on the old man’s shoulder, and squeezed. “Leave her be.”

The man turned, spoiling for a quarrel, but when he saw Gendry’s size he thought better of it. “Your sister, is she? What kind of brother are you? I’d never bring no sister of mine to the Peach, that I wouldn’t.” He got up from the bench and moved off muttering, in search of a new friend.

“Why did you say that?” Arya hopped to her feet. “You’re not my brother.”“That’s right,” he said angrily. “I’m too bloody lowborn to be kin to m’lady high.”Arya was taken aback by the fury in his voice. “That’s not the way I meant it.”“Yes it is.” He sat down on the bench, cradling a cup of wine between his hands. “Go away. I want to drink this wine in peace. Then maybe I’ll go find that black-haired girl and ring her bell for her.”

“But…”“I said, go away. M’lady.”Arya whirled and left him there. A stupid bullheaded bastard boy, that’s all he is. He could ring all the bells he wanted, it was nothing to her.

So maybe Gendry did try to change his social status to get closer to Arya by joining the brotherhood without banners, when he noticed the divide between them, and Lem was reminding him being a lowborn knight wouldn’t change anything. Sadly there is no Gendry POV so we can’t tell. 

So does Lem’s quote refer to Arya and Gendry’s relationship? Yes. Am i grasping at straws? A little. However GRRM has an interesting way of writing and alot of the time he will leave breadcrumbs for us to follow, little hints that lead/hint to the bigger picture. I honestly do think it was a wink towards their relationship and some of Gendry’s intentions behind joining.

Hope you enjoyed my TED Talk

trail.content_raw:
Hey, Don’t apologise. Yes its from A Storm of Swords - Chapter 39 (Arya’s POV). 

In this chapter Gendry pledges to the brotherhood without banners and is knighted. I couldn’t find the whole chapter but i found a small section. 

“A smith can find a welcome most anywhere. A skilled armorer even more so. Why would you choose to stay with us?“

Arya watched Gendry screw up his stupid face, thinking. “At the hollow hill, what you said about being King Robert’s men, and brothers, I liked that. I liked that you gave the Hound a trial. Lord Bolton just hanged folk or took off their heads, and Lord Tywin and Ser Amory were the same. I’d sooner smith for you.”

“We got plenty of mail needs mending, m'lord,” Jack reminded Lord Beric. “Most we took off the dead, and there’s holes where the death came through.”

“You must be a lackwit, boy,” said Lem. “We’re outlaws. Lowborn scum, most of us, excepting his lordship. Don’t think it’ll be like Tom’s fool songs neither. You won’t be stealing no kisses from a princess, nor riding in no tourneys in stolen armor. You join us, you’ll end with your neck in a noose, or your head mounted up above some castle gate.”

“It’s no more than they’d do for you,” said Gendry.

“Aye, that’s so,” said Jack-Be-Lucky cheerfully. “The crows await us all. M'lord, the boy seems brave enough, and we do have need of what he brings us. Take him, says Jack.”

“And quick,” suggested Harwin, chuckling, “before the fever passes and he comes to his senses.” A wan smile crossed Lord Beric’s lips. “Thoros, my sword.”

This time the lightning lord did not set the blade afire, but merely laid it light on Gendry’s shoulder. “Gendry, do you swear before the eyes of gods and men to defend those who cannot defend themselves, to protect all women and children, to obey your captains, your liege lord, and your king, to fight bravely when needed and do such other tasks as are laid upon you, however hard or humble or dangerous they may be?”

“I do, m'lord.”

The marcher lord moved the sword from the right shoulder to the left, and said, “Arise Ser Gendry, knight of the hollow hill, and be welcome to our brotherhood.”

Lemoncloak is basically saying that living as a outlaw (criminal) isn’t like all the fairy tales, its going to be hard and you’ll most likely end up dead. Alot of old songs/stories about outlaws (For example Robin Hood), mention falling in love with a princess or a lady. Which in those times for a “lowborn” would be next to impossible, almost taboo. As far as it relating to Arya’s and Gendry’s Relationship there’s an argument for both sides.

Harwin took one look at them and burst out laughing, and Anguy smiled one of his stupid freckly smiles and said, “Are we certain this one is a highborn lady?” But Lem gave Gendry a clout alongside the head. “You want to fight, fight with me! She’s a girl, and half your age! You keep your hands off o’ her, you hear me?”

“I started it ” said Arya. “Gendry was just talking.”

“Leave the boy, Lem,” said Harwin. “Arya did start it, I have no doubt. She was much the same at Winterfell.”

In this scene Lem is clearly reminding Gendry that wrestling with Arya Stark is inappropriate, she’s a girl and half his age. He doesn’t mention Arya’s social status but i have the feeling like its implied. By saying this i feel like Lem is suggesting that the play fight has some sort of sexual/flirting undertones behind it. 

Now if you go back to Chapter 39 you could argue he’s hinting to Gendry that joining the brotherhood won’t improve his social class, he won’t be able to kiss princesses or competing in competitions. He’ll still be lowborn and nothing will change. 

Gendry is well aware of Arya’s status and the divide that this makes, this is made clear in the books. 

In this scene (Chapter 34) Arya meets a young lord and they share a pleasant conversation, Gendry is clearly irritated by this.

Poor Ned seemed to grow more miserable with every mile. “When I wear my helm, the rain beats against the steel and gives me headaches,” he complained. “But when I take it off, my hair gets soaked and sticks to my face and in my mouth.”

“You have a knife,” Gendry suggested. “If your hair annoys you so much, shave your bloody head.”

He doesn’t like Ned. The squire seemed nice enough to Arya; maybe a little shy, but good- natured…

“You have a House?” That was stupid; he was a squire, of course he had a House. “Who are you?”

“My lady?” Ned looked embarrassed. “I’m Edric Dayne, the… the Lord of Starfall.”

Behind them, Gendry groaned. “Lords and ladies,” he proclaimed in a disgusted tone. Arya plucked a withered crabapple off a passing branch and whipped it at him, bouncing it off his thick bull head. “Ow,” he said. “That hurt.” He felt the skin above his eye. “What kind of lady throws crabapples at people?”

“The bad kind,” said Arya, suddenly contrite. She turned back to Ned. “I’m sorry I didn’t know who you were. My lord” …

“That’s not so. He loved my lady mother.”“I’m sure he did, my lady, but -”“She was the only one he loved.”“He must have found that bastard under a cabbage leaf, then,” Gendry said behind them.Arya wished she had another crabapple to bounce off his face. “My father had honor,” she said angrily. “And we weren’t talking to you anyway.

An old man sat down beside her. “Well, aren’t you a pretty little peach?” His breath smelled near as foul as the dead men in the cages, and his little pig eyes were crawling up and down her. “Does my sweet peach have a name?”

For half a heartbeat she forgot who she was supposed to be. She wasn’t any peach, but she couldn’t be Arya Stark either, not here with some smelly drunk she did not know. “I’m…”

“She’s my sister.” Gendry put a heavy hand on the old man’s shoulder, and squeezed. “Leave her be.”

The man turned, spoiling for a quarrel, but when he saw Gendry’s size he thought better of it. “Your sister, is she? What kind of brother are you? I’d never bring no sister of mine to the Peach, that I wouldn’t.” He got up from the bench and moved off muttering, in search of a new friend.

“Why did you say that?” Arya hopped to her feet. “You’re not my brother.”“That’s right,” he said angrily. “I’m too bloody lowborn to be kin to m’lady high.”Arya was taken aback by the fury in his voice. “That’s not the way I meant it.”“Yes it is.” He sat down on the bench, cradling a cup of wine between his hands. “Go away. I want to drink this wine in peace. Then maybe I’ll go find that black-haired girl and ring her bell for her.”

“But…”“I said, go away. M’lady.”Arya whirled and left him there. A stupid bullheaded bastard boy, that’s all he is. He could ring all the bells he wanted, it was nothing to her.

However GRRM has an interesting way of writing and alot of the time he will leave breadcrumbs for us to follow, little hints that lead/hint to the bigger picture. I honestly do think it was a wink towards their relationship and some of Gendry’s intentions behind joining.

Hope you enjoyed my TED Talk

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

summary: It always irritates me when I see posts or comments that suggest Arya and Gendry should get married but just switch their roles,...
body: It always irritates me when I see posts or comments that suggest Arya and Gendry should get married but just switch their roles, meaning that Arya should take on the lord’s duties and Gendry the lady’s duties. Because that‘s not feminist or empowering. It doesn‘t challenge the roles at all. The submissive and restrictive role of the lady stays the same. The only difference is, that it is given to the man which essentially would only result in sexism towards men. The problem is not solved by switching the roles between the genders. The roles need to be changed. There needs to be a power balance. The lady should have an equal amount of power as her husband and should not be bound to stay at home and take care of the children. She should not be forced to compromise her own dreams and goals in order to maintain a stable family life. Both man and woman need to contribute to that. Giving the lord‘s duties to the woman and the lady‘s duties to the man is not progressive for the westerosi society. It will only end up with one gender being at a disadvantge again. True equality is defined by the reconstruction of gender roles and not the reversal of those.

True equality is defined by the reconstruction of gender roles and not the reversal of those.

title: friendly reminder
body: storm’s end is one of the most easterly westerosi strongholds and with the exception of dragonstone is the easternmost seat of the great houses, so arya sailing west means that she is traveling as far as physically possible from gendry

blog.name: ablogthatishenceforthmine
blog.title: A Blog That is Henceforth Mine
blog.description:
Alexa, 21, bi
I'm just a girl with too many obsessions and too much anxiety

title: My Top 10 Favorite GOT Characters
body:
1. Sansa Stark

2. Theon Greyjoy

3. Arya Stark

4. Tywin Lannister

5. Cersei Lannister

6. Sandor Clegane

7. Margaery Tyrell

8. Olenna Tyrell

9. Ygritte

10. Oberyn Martell

reblog.comment:

Hot Pie: Oh, Arry. You don't have to worry about my...
body:
Arya: Gendry, remember how we were worried about Hot Pie's F-U-T-U-R-E?
Hot Pie: Oh, Arry. You don't have to worry about my furniture.

dialogue.name: Arya
dialogue.label: Arya:
dialogue.phrase: Gendry, remember how we were worried about Hot Pie's F-U-T-U-R-E?

dialogue.phrase: Oh, Arry. You don't have to worry about my furniture.
